name: nytimes
text: The Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade is still on. But the event — which has taken place every year since 1924, except for three years during World War II — has been scaled down and the millions who typically attend have been told to stay home. https://t.co/wbBRpLh76m

name: nytimes
text: Two Houston-area men have been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that they negotiated a deal to sell 50 million nonexistent N95 masks to a foreign government in an attempt to defraud it out of over $317 million, federal officials said. https://t.co/eESKgaAdbR

text: "In Argentina, Diego Maradona’s homeland — which declared three days of national mourning once his death was announced — there has long been a church in his honor. For many, Maradona was a quasi-religious experience," writes @RorySmith. https://t.co/KcsF3hkOiI

name: nytimes
text:
Some coronavirus survivors say loose teeth have fallen out without any blood. Others complain of sensitive gums, or of teeth turning grey or chipping. 

People who already have dental problems may see them aggravated by the virus, some experts say. https://t.co/MuWK9a1rhE

name: nytimes
text:
"Just thinking of yourself in a higher light and always being optimistic will allow you to do the things you need to get done in your life." 

Demetria Mack started college last year. She had to move back in with her foster mother when the pandemic hit. https://t.co/e4n0rlLaPs

name: nytimes
text: An unlikely fight is breaking out over President-elect Joe Biden’s choice for agriculture secretary, pitting Democrats eager to emphasize issues like hunger and nutrition against traditionalists who believe the department should represent rural America. https://t.co/2V9Z7RjR6w

text: South Korea reported 583 new cases of the coronavirus on Thursday, the biggest daily caseload since early March, as health officials struggled to contain a third wave. https://t.co/dZoDjy49kS

for the palette of Nebraska

name: nytimes
text:
In Opinion

text: Almost all of England must adhere to the two most severe sets of coronavirus restrictions when a national lockdown ends next week, the government said. London and Liverpool have escaped the most stringent rules. https://t.co/JCPg0r6FLj

text: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia said he had ordered a final military offensive into the capital of the northern region of Tigray, a major escalation of a conflict that rights organizations worry will lead to large civilian casualties. https://t.co/H5AR8Eb6Xw

name: nytimes
text: At the height of the pandemic in April, Simon Gronowski, a Holocaust survivor, began playing jazz tunes on the piano from his apartment window in Brussels, bringing light to his neighbors at a dark moment. https://t.co/t70kedw0VM

name: nytimes
text:
Lire en français: Au plus fort de la pandémie, Simon Gronowski, un rescapé de l'Holocauste, jouait des airs de jazz au piano électrique à sa fenêtre, à Bruxelles, pour réconforter le voisinage.
https://t.co/20Wdh98XQF

name: nytimes
text: Gov. Philip Murphy urged New Jersey school districts to open for some face-to-face teaching. Such decisions often require school boards to buck powerful teachers unions and to live with the risk of outbreaks as the coronavirus surges. https://t.co/2s2yTXZrl1

name: nytimes
text: Despite rising infection rates across most of the country, this Thanksgiving, Americans are “still absolutely gonna America anyway.” Here are some ways how people are solving — or failing to solve — the ethical dilemma of the holidays. https://t.co/edG6y8EiVk

name: nytimes
text:
As Americans gather for Thanksgiving in a difficult year, we asked poets laureate across the U.S. what we should be thankful for. In poetry and prose they told us: family, friends, hospital workers, cherished natural landscapes and more.
https://t.co/QQxw2Ne1g0

name: nytimes
text: Virginia’s poet laureate, Luisa A. Igloria, recalled the toppling of Confederate monuments in the racial reckoning of the summer and gave thanks “for the thousand-thousand bodies / marching in the hearts of grieving, / inflamed cities.” https://t.co/QQxw2Ne1g0 https://t.co/OnPdOUf4mt

name: nytimes
text: Kari Gunter-Seymour of Ohio reflected on the use of Zoom — “a window of windows inside a dollhouse” — to connect with one another. https://t.co/QQxw2MWqos https://t.co/ghSijANyrA

name: nytimes
text: “I am thankful for friends,” wrote Nebraska’s state poet, Matt Mason, “for the palette of Nebraska / sunsets, for my family, / still alive, thank God.” https://t.co/QQxw2Ne1g0 https://t.co/cQoMrpOvV1

name: nytimes
text: All the poets reflected an appreciation for both regional grit and more universal blessings, and many wrote of the humanity and fellowship around them. Read more poems from The Poet Laureate Project here: https://t.co/QQxw2Ne1g0

name: nytimes
text:
Four years ago, Wanda Dench accidentally invited Jamal Hinton over for Thanksgiving. Thus began a holiday tradition that has charmed the world.

This year, they felt a major loss from the pandemic at their table.
